intro: Linodendron lagetta, commonly known as the golden mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of host trees, primarily in the family Rutaceae. It is native to parts of South America, particularly Brazil, and thrives in tropical and subtropical regions. The plant has small, elliptical leaves that are usually arranged in opposite pairs along its stem. Its flowers are white or pale yellow, and it produces small, fleshy berries that are often consumed by birds. Linodendron lagetta plays a role in local ecosystems by providing food for wildlife and contributing to the biodiversity of its habitat.
